prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - NE group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 detection of disks in singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the North-East grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions. The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or Mdisk = 3 x 10-6 Msun using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected CO(3-2) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - NW group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 detections of disks in singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the North-West grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions. The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or Mdisk = 3 x 10-6 Msun using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected CO(3-2) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus multiples - NE group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections in closely spaced multiples with high angular resolution. These sources are the North-East grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these close multiple systems (< 1), the highest angular resolution of 0.18 is requested, to ensure that the individual components can be separated. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions. The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or Mdisk = 3 x 10-6 Msun using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected CO(3-2) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus multiples - SW group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections in closely spaced multiples with high angular resolution. These sources are the South-West grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these close multiple systems (< 1), the highest angular resolution of 0.18 is requested, to ensure that the individual components can be separated. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions. The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or Mdisk = 3 x 10-6 Msun using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected CO(3-2) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - Southern group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections of singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the Southern grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions. The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or Mdisk = 3 x 10-6 Msun using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected CO(3-2) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe 69 single and multiple young stellar systems in Taurus to answer how protoplanetary disk mass depends on both stellar mass and multiplicity. While previous surveys have demonstrated a clear correlation between stellar and disk mass, most sources below spectral type M3 are undetected and it is not known if the same dependence holds down to the stellar mass limit. Our Cycle 0 observations of wide binaries in Taurus detected disk masses down to 10-4 MSun and revealed a range of disk mass distributions. ALMAs unmatched combination of sensitivity and resolution enables us to observe a complete sample to tackle this issue; these systems will be observed at a sensitivity level over 10 times better than previous large surveys of this region. The sample has been chosen to provide complete coverage of all stars in the disk-only phase by targeting undetected single stars and undetected or unresolved multiple systems. Using these new 1.3mm (Band 6) continuum fluxes as a measure of outer disk mass, combined with the wealth of ancillary data on Taurus, we will be able to establish the influence of stellar mass and multiplicity on the potential for planet formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Swarthmore College
